key_points: Drivers in the Southeast experienced long lines at gas stations due to panic-buying after a hack of the Colonial Pipeline.
The Colonial Pipeline, delivering 45% of the East Coast's fuel, was shut down due to a cyberattack, prompting concerns over fuel supply.
Government officials and energy analysts clarified there is no gasoline shortage, but a distribution issue due to the pipeline shutdown.
Officials are seeking alternative transportation routes for fuel to mitigate the disruption.
In North Carolina, 28% of gas stations were out of fuel; in some areas like Raleigh-Durham, the number was much higher at 72%.
North Carolina Governor Roy Cooper declared a state of emergency to ease fuel transportation into the state.
The national average price for a gallon of gasoline rose above $3 for the first time since 2016.
The AAA predicts over 37 million Americans will travel during the Memorial Day weekend, expecting a significant increase in fuel demand.
The U.S. government is coordinating efforts to prevent fuel shortages, including allowing certain states to transport overweight loads of fuel.
The Department of Homeland Security is prepared to review Jones Act waiver requests to alleviate fuel shortages.
spokespersons: Jamar Gatison (Construction worker and Uber Eats driver)
